g.text: systemic financial risks arising due to climate change and address the legal
Challenges remain with regards to overlapping definitions of sustainable and ESG investment
opportunities, which also vary depending on social norms and pathways. There is also a general need
extensive ESG disclosure on a corporate level, against the background of emerging mandatory
impact reporting for asset managers in some regions. A movement is building towards sustainable
investment strategies and increased sustainable development awarenes
, which points to the ability of civil society movements, such as
divestment campaigns, to have some influence on investor b
influences such as climate risk disclosure initiatives and regulations.
. Developing countries make up two thirds of the world population,
carry carbon intensive economies where 70% of investments need to be conducted to limit warming to
. The focus for climate investments has been on China, USA, Europe, India and the G
but studies highlight Paris and SDG attention should be devoted to Afri
The “special needs, circumstances and vulnerability” of Africa, LDC and SIDS nations are recognised
These nations currently contribute very little to global emissions.
growing economies, including the vast Africa continent roughly the size of China, Europe, USA, India
with a 1 billion population expected to double by 2050, growing reliance
cheap’ biomass (charcoal use and deforestation) amid rising urbanization and
collectively these nations hold large leap
transition as well as risks of infrastructure lock
This could mobilise global savings, scale up
development of local capital markets for accelerated low carbon investment and adaptation in low and
lower middle income countries as well as
deprive developing countries of valuable resources
funding sources is important at a time hard
Otherwise, the structure of voluntary, nationally oriented, and financially fragmented arrangements
e Paris Agreement (see Chapter 17) could lead to ‘regional rivalry’ (SSP 3) pathways
The benefits are many times greater than apparent costs in terms of expected
e in global GHG emissions and attaining SDGs. These could even generate large ‘win
opportunities back in capital source countries which will benefit from a flow back in import demand
literature on policy options in mobilising capital for Paris and SDG
a) development of national just transition strategies
100 billion USD commitment on a grant
equivalent basis to support NDCs that integrate policies on
19 recovery, climate action, sustainable development and equity b)
public funds on diverse sources of private capi

ordination of project preparation and development of project pipelines by infrastructure co
